Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Low-Energy Electron Scattering From Uracil and Thymine
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the early 2000's it has been understood that free electrons in biological environments are able to interact with, and cause damage to, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). This is in spite of the generally slow speeds of these electrons. This finding carried significant implications in various fields of biomedicine, in particular those that employ radiation as a therapeutic measure. This is due to the fact that such radiation creates free electrons within the body, which effectively constitutes a secondary radiation dose. However, to this day the effect of these electrons is largely excluded from most dosage calculations, in part due to the paucity of fundamental data describing how free electrons interact with molecules that make up DNA. Experimental physics techniques to measure electron interaction "cross sections," a quantity that describes the chemistry of a molecule by characterizing its physical size and shape, are well established for many targets. These techniques require molecules to be in the gas phase, however, whereas commercial samples of most biological molecules are solids (powders) at room temperature. While changing a substance from solid to gas is possible by simply heating it, this approach is incompatible with other crucial aspects of most standard experimental techniques. The research supported by this project will commission a new apparatus that will employ new measurement techniques, compatible with heated samples, to make measurements of electron interactions with DNA molecules. Improving our fundamental understanding of electron interactions with biological molecules will allow the effects of radiation on biological material to be more accurately included into radiation dosage calculations, which may ultimately enable the radiation to be better targeted to where it is needed most.

This project will commission a new electron scattering spectrometer for the purpose of making measurements of the total, total elastic, and elastic differential cross sections for the nucleobases, with a view to making measurements of uracil and thymine within the time frame of the current project. Under this project, a beam of electrons is sent through a large volume of a heated gas cell containing a vapor of the target under consideration. The use of a large volume cell, rather than a traditional crossed beam technique, allows for a sufficient number of electron-target interactions to achieve reasonable statistics in the signal, and removes complications with normalizing the measurements since the target volume and density are easily characterized. However, the approach defeats using the detector location to determine the final state momentum of the scattered particle, as the scattering location is not well localized. Instead, this work will employ a modified version of the "magnetic beamline" technique, pioneered at the University of California San Diego for studies of positron interactions with atoms and molecules, whereby a strong magnetic field guides all scattered electrons along the spectrometer axis to a detector, and a retarding electric field is used to determine their momentum components parallel to and perpendicular to the spectrometer axis, thus determining their final state momentum. In addition to making these measurements on nucleobase molecules, this project will demonstrate improvements to the magnetic beamline technique, by demonstrating methods for generating high energy-resolution electron beams in strong magnetic fields. In addition, this work aims to use fast pulsing techniques to address the loss of information that is currently inherent in the technique due to reflection of electrons scattered in the backwards scattering direction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a new electron scattering apparatus designed to study electron interactions for molecules of biological relevance. Electron scattering from biomolecules is topical due to its applicability to modelling of electron transport and energy deposition in biological environments. Better understanding of electron interactions with biological matter in turn will facilitate improved modelling and process control of radiotherapuetic treatments, such as are administered to cancer suffers, with a view to better targeting and control of the administered ionizing radiation for improved patient safety.

The primary goal of this project was to develop an apparatus that could measure electron scattering "cross sections" for biologically relevant targets, to apply this apparatus to such a study and to develop technologies that could be applied more broadly to other electron scattering apparatus.

Intellectual Merit

One key limitation to developing a database of electron-biomolecule cross sections has been technological incompatibilities with standard equipment used to consider electron scattering phenomena (which require the target molecule to be present as a molecular beam) and many biologically relevant targets, which are liquids or powders at room temperature. While such targets may be heated to form molecular beams, this technique defeats most standard techniques used to determine the density of the beam, which precludes determination of the absolute size of the measurements and severly limits their utility.

This project developed and commissioned a new apparatus that overcomes a technique to overcome this limitation, developed from a similar technique widely applied for positron collision studies. The key premise of the revised technique is to use a large volume gas cell to contain the target vapor (instead of a small volume gas beam), and then to overcome the geometric constraints imposed by the cell by employing magnetic and electric fields to image scattered particles onto a stationary detector. The commissioned apparatus will have a long shelf life and provide much needed data to compile a thorough collision cross section database.

This project also considered the problem of electron scattering from the most important biomolecule, water. While a well studied target, a large (around 25%) discrepency existed in the literature regarding the magnitude of water's elastic cross section. This discrepancy is critical as the elastic cross section both directly determines how effectively electrons can move through biological matter and is widely used as the calibration standard in measurements that consider energy deposition. The literature discrepancy arose due to ambiguities in establishing water's gas diameter. The true "effective" gas diameter is ambiguous for water, which is a geometrically small molecule, but which has a large dipole moment that allows an electrostatic interaction at larger distances. This parameter is generally a critical assumption in standard electron collision measurements. In our approach, we were able to make our own quantiative estimate of the gas diameter and establish accurate values for the water cross section.

Broader Impacts

This project developed new technolgoies that will allow the use of high moentum resolution electron guns in high magnetic field environments. This advancement will permit modelling research in high field environments that have important application to medicinal chemistry and plasma environments.

This project supported research projects for over a dozen undergraduate research students and two master's students. These students developed both laboratory research skills and scientific presentation skills through presenting data at professional research accomplishments. CSUF is an accreditted hispanic serving institution, and the students that worked on this project primarily from underrepresented minorities in physics, including over 50% women and the predominant majority identifying as hispanic (national participation rates in physics are below 25% for both groups). This project thus had a disproportionately positive impact on under-represented physics minority students and contributed to their academic and future success.
